newsitem.title: GERMANY: Issing - homework ahead for Germany to meet EMU goal.
newsitem.headline: Issing - homework ahead for Germany to meet EMU goal.

text.p: Bundesbank chief economist Otmar Issing said on Thursday Germany had a lot of "homework" ahead on its budgetary position in order to qualify for the launch of Europe's single currency in January 1999.
Issing, speaking to reporters, also said he did not believe a cut in German interest rates would solve the country's problems, but would actually lead to an increase in long-term market rates.
"Germany has homework to do if we are to keep to the Maastricht deficit criterion," Issing said.

The Maastricht Treaty calls on countries to reduce their budget deficits to three percent of gross domestic product, a target Germany and other countries are widely expected to overshoot despite politicians' commitment to the goal.
Issing declined comment on fears expressed by French Finance Minister Dominique Strauss-Kahn on Thursday that the French budget deficit this year could be 3.4 percent of GDP or higher.
Issing said that in the realm of public finances, it was important that countries display sustainability.
"The primary concern for public finances in EMU is sustainability," he said.
He believed that easing German interest rates at present would be counter productive.
"I am convinced that a cut in rates would lead to a rise in long term market rates and damage confidence in the mark. That is not the solution to Germany's problems," he said.
Germany has kept its headline discount and Lombard rates at 2.5 percent and 4.5 percent respectively since April 1996.
The Bundesbank reduced the securities repurchase rate, or repo, to three percent last August and has not changed rates since.
